item.title: Will Anyone Crack The Secret Sauce Of Facebook's Keyword Search?
item.description: One of the important steps on the way to Zynga's success on Facebook was their judicious ad spend to acquire users. An aggressive and impossible to miss marketing strategy that kept the per user acquisition cost just under the average revenue per user saw the company's name become the shorthand for the viral clicking games, and drove their high valuation.
item.dc:creator: Ewan Spence

item.title: 2012: The First Digital Election
item.description: Guest post written by Paul Springer and Mel Carson
item.dc:creator: Eric Savitz

item.title: How Information Security Drives SMB Growth Partnerships
item.description: Guest post written by Brian Burch
item.dc:creator: Eric Savitz

item.title: 'Halo 4' Is Easily One Of The Best Looking Xbox 360 Games Of All Time
item.description: Halo 4 is quite possibly the best looking game released on the Xbox 360 in that console's nearly eight-year lifetime, and certainly boasts the best graphics in the Halo franchise.
item.dc:creator: Erik Kain

item.title: The Nintendo Wii U Has A Big Problem: Sibling Rivalry
item.description: Sharing is hard. This is a lesson the Wii U may teach parents and children in painful detail.
item.dc:creator: Erik Kain

item.title: Could An Internet Of Things Startup Be The Next Microsoft? Three Hobby Kits Hold Promise
item.description: In January 1975, Bill Gates saw a headline in Popular Electronics for a hobby kit that would change his life. It announced "Project Breakthrough! World's First Minicomputer Kit to Rival Commercial Models "Altair 8800."
item.dc:creator: Elise Ackerman

item.title: Good Luck: Why the Year's Best Business Book Says You'll Probably Need It
item.description: I just finished reading the most enjoyable business book I’ve read in a long time – although relegating “The Success Equation,” by Legg Mason Chief Investment Strategist Michael J. Mauboussin to this category would be a grave disservice, significantly understating its sophistication and selling short its achievement.
item.dc:creator: David Shaywitz

item.title: Google And The FTC's Investigation: A Cautionary Tale
item.description: Guest post written by James C. Cooper
item.dc:creator: Eric Savitz

item.title: Finally an Enterprise
item.description: Lady Gaga’s Little Monsters online community, designed by Backplane, quickly attracted a million unique visitors soon after launching in July 2012.  Without relying on Facebook, Lady Gaga is able to host a specific interest, purpose-driven global community where fans and other stakeholders could exchange ideas, co-create adventures and otherwise bond in ways that boost participation in all her profit centers.  Further, interaction on the online community and at concerts — and mobile conversations with each other at both—leads to real time insights for what most matters to her fans, and ways to rapidly involve them in the activities that most fuel Lady Gaga’s brand and financial growth.
item.dc:creator: Kare Anderson

item.title: Cardiac Controversy: A Study That Says Chelation Helps Heart Patients, But Doctors Don't Believe It
item.description: A government-funded study seems to show a benefit for heart-attack patients who receive a controversial treatment called chelation, an arduous process that is used by some alternative medicine practitioners but not by most mainstream doctors. But top cardiologists, including the study's lead author, expressed caution about treating patients based on the result. Some even doubted the study's validity and one warned the study could lead to patients being harmed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Herper

item.title: NIH Trial Gives Surprising Boost To Chelation Therapy
item.description: With a result that is likely to surprise and baffle much of the mainstream medical community, a large NIH-sponsored trial has turned up the first substantial evidence in support of chelation therapy for patients with coronary disease.  Known as TACT (Trial to Assess Chelation Therapy),  the highly controversial trial was presented today at the AHA by Gervasio Lamas. The trial was sponsored by two NIH institutes, the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine and the National Heart Lung and Blood Institute.
item.dc:creator: Larry Husten

item.title: FREEDOM Lends Strong Support To CABG For Diabetics With Multivessel Disease
item.description: Editor's note: The embargo on FREEDOM was lifted early after a press release was published by mistake.)
item.dc:creator: Larry Husten

item.title: ARCTIC Blows A Cold Wind On Platelet Function Tests
item.description: The use of platelet-function tests to monitor and guide antiplatelet therapy in PCI patients has sparked heated debate. Cardiologists have sought to reconcile biological plausibility with the absence of clinical evidence. Now the ARCTIC (Assessment by a Double Randomization of a Conventional Antiplatelet Strategy versus a Monitoring-guided Strategy for Drug-Eluting Stent Implantation versus Continuation One Year after Stenting) trial brings cold comfort to supporters of the monitoring strategy.
item.dc:creator: Larry Husten

item.title: ASPIRE: Aspirin An Attractive Alternative After First VTE
item.description: It is unclear what the best approach is for the long-term treatment of people who have had a first unprovoked episode of venous thromboembolism (VTE). Although warfarin is effective at preventing a recurrence, it is inconvenient and raises the risk for bleeding. Newer anticoagulants have not been tested or approved for this population.
item.dc:creator: Larry Husten

item.title: Hurricane Sandy Shows Nuclear Is Safe
item.description: Since WWII, nuclear has become the poster child for extreme events. Ironically, nuclear energy in America is now the poster child for emergency preparedness.
item.dc:creator: James Conca

item.title: Big Data Debunks View That Job-Hoppers Make Bad Hires
item.description: Guest post written by Jim Meyerle
item.dc:creator: Eric Savitz

item.title: Tracking Innovation through Boxcars, Boxing, Bears and Automobiles
item.description: I am fortunate to be able to work with people on the cutting edge of innovation. They often identify an answer before most of us even know there is a question.  The path followed by Jamyn Edis and his colleague, Brian Langel, offers a vivid illustration of the process of discovery that just may lead to a sea change in the way that we think about our cars.
item.dc:creator: Alan McGlade

item.title: On Quora, a Reasonable, Well Mannered Political Discussion
item.description: Not too long ago, a basic question was posted to Quora, a Palo Alto based question-and-answer site, about President Obama. “What is President Barack Obama like in person?” it asked. Three people answered the question, including Peter Marquez, once the White House’s director for space policy.
item.dc:creator: Alex Kantrowitz

item.title: Infographic: The Four Most Common Mobile Deployment Strategies
item.description: With mobile devices flooding businesses from every corner of the organization, CIOs must act proactively to set policies to manage them. This is the next frontier in the fight against corporate security breaches. With that in mind, world renown security company Symantec has prepared an infographic for our
item.dc:creator: Mark Fidelman

item.title: The Nintendo Wii U Has A Big Problem: Sibling Rivalry
item.description: Sharing is hard. This is a lesson the Wii U may teach parents and children in painful detail.
item.dc:creator: Erik Kain

item.title: Hurricane Sandy Shows Nuclear Is Safe
item.description: Hurricane Sandy is just the latest in a growing number of severe weather events. Last week was also a surprise quiz on what infrastructure stands up to extreme weather and what doesn’t.
item.dc:creator: James Conca

item.title: Stock Tumbles and This Guy Says Apple Has Peaked; Great Companies Aren't One-Act Plays
item.description: Christopher Mims, writing on Quartz, the Atlantic’s smart business-and-economics blog, either has superb timing or is actually incredibly influential. Or both. His piece, “Five reasons Apple (AAPL) has peaked—for real, this time,” coincides with a steep tumble in the gadget maker’s shares.
item.dc:creator: YCharts

item.title: 'Halo 4' Is Easily One Of The Best Looking Xbox 360 Games Of All Time
item.description: Halo 4 is quite possibly the best looking game released on the Xbox 360 in that console's nearly eight-year lifetime, and certainly boasts the best graphics in the Halo franchise.
item.dc:creator: Erik Kain

item.title: Halo 4 Screenshots
item.description: Screenshots from Halo 4, the Xbox 360 exclusive which launches November 6th.
item.dc:creator: Erik Kain

item.title: Undisclosed Foreign Bank Accounts? They're Even More Explosive Now
item.description: In 2009, UBS paid $780 million to the IRS and upended Swiss banking forever by handing over Americans. Many other banks have followed suit, some quietly, some not. IRS amnesty programs in 2009, 2011 and today have offered a limited form of relief. But generally, Americans caught in this pickle have had no choice.
item.dc:creator: Robert W. Wood

item.title: Wreck-It Ralph Earns Record $49.1 Million High Score At The Box Office For Disney
item.description: In a twist, Hurricane (or super storm) Sandy actually helped drive up Hollywood box office numbers this weekend in the Northeast, where kids were off school on Friday and people over the weekend were seeking entertainment refuge from a very bad week of flooding, power loss and devastation.
item.dc:creator: John Gaudiosi

item.title: ECB: "Roots Of Bitcoin Can Be Found In The Austrian School Of Economics"
item.description: The ECB (European Central Bank) has produced the first official central bank study of the decentralized cryptographic money known as bitcoin, Virtual Currency Schemes. Ignoring for a moment the ECB's condescending and derogatory use of the virtual currency phrase and scheme phrase, the study produced at least one landmark achievement. In
item.dc:creator: Jon Matonis

item.title: Why The Occupy Movement Reminds Me Of Real Democracy, Mr Obama
item.description: One change that I've noted a few times here on Re:Thinking Innovation: The way we deal with opinion. We used to think of opinion as an analytical entity, something a pollster might collect from time to time, like during elections. Or as the provenance of leaders, thought leaders, real leaders.
item.dc:creator: Haydn Shaughnessy

item.title: The Game Theory of Brain Enhancement
item.description:
Around two years ago I wrote about how brain enhancing technologies were inevitable from a game theoretic point of view. Here is how I put it:
Because nobody will be able to tell whether you’re using it, genius will be indistinguishable from brain mounted computer use. If nobody uses it you will have the advantages over your coworkers that perfect memory would give you today. If everybody but you uses it you will have all the disadvantages that someone with really terrible memory has today. When everyone else uses brain mounted computers, those without them will look forgetful and unknowledgeable. It will be a dominant strategy in the same way that optional genius would be today; only extreme individuals will choose to reject it.
Now in an interesting new article on how technology is increasingly allowing us to enhance our capabilities, David Duncan offers a glimpse of the game theory of brain enhancement in action:
Over the last couple of years during talks and lectures, I have asked thousands of people a hypothetical question that goes like this: “If I could offer you a pill that allowed your child to increase his or her memory by 25 percent, would you give it to them?”
item.dc:creator: Adam Ozimek
